subtitle: I grew up in New York and Maryland and I
was born to a medical family my father
was a doctor so he had a kind of science
side to her family but my family also
was part of a what people would probably
call a fundamentalist sect so my
religious background was very strict and
and very intense so really a lot of my
story has been trying to put together
that kind of scientific background very
passionate religious background and then
I was also very interested in music in
the arts so that kind of artistic
dimension as well I my first career was
as an English professor I taught College
English and I also was very committed in
my faith I'd had a kind of falling out
with fundamentalism but also felt that
the spiritual dimension of life was very
important to me so some years into being
an English teacher I became part of a
experimental and non-traditional little
Christian congregation that formed
outside of Washington DC I ended up
becoming the pastor or spiritual leader
of that group and I did that for 20 24
years during that time I started asking
a lot of deeper questions about theology
and spirituality and and I began writing
about that and my first book was
published in 1998 and in 2006 I ended up
leaving the pastorate because I was
doing a lot of writing and getting a lot
of invitations to speak about what I was
writing about so for these last several
years I've lived as a kind of public
speaker and writer and I have a number
of activist causes that I'm committed to
entrenched belief systems engage people
in meaning really that I think the the
practical function of those belief
systems is they situate people in a
story that gives them great meaning and
the community that lives by that story
creates a deep sense of belonging so one
of the first things I think it's
important to remember about any
passionately committed community that
has its own belief systems is that
people are getting something very very
valuable out of participation in that
group and very often we see some
negative consequences of that for
example if that group in its sense of
who we are the us miss of that group can
create a lot of hostility toward anybody
who's part of another us or who's part
of that as far as that group is
concerned so I think when we start to
realize some of the negative side
effects of that of that us them dualism
we can't just attack it without
realizing to take that away from people
it's taking away things that are
precious to them so one of the things I
try to do is first take seriously the
need for meaning the need for a story
the need for belonging and and and not
underestimate the personal psychological
social benefits that people derive from
that and then maybe we can help people
engage in a in a quest to evaluate those
belief systems and to find ways of
achieving the same meaning and the same
a similar sense of belonging
without being wedded to beliefs that are
highly suspect and that bring all kinds
of negative unintended consequences
I think first of all some people really
hardly ever if ever question their
belief system it works incredibly well
for them and sometimes their way of
making a living depends on it
the power that they exercised over
others depends on it
I mean there's an awful lot of
reinforcements when you're in a belief
system and if you say it that way at the
center of the belief system there's
virtually no questioning but at the
fringes there's more and more
questioning the closer you get to the
edge partly because at the edge people
encounter people from other belief
systems and so now my way of seeing the
world isn't the only one when you're in
the center you maybe have never met
anyone who doesn't share those beliefs
and and of course in today's world with
movies and television internet and
travel now there's a lot more margin and
a lot more vulnerable Center and so the
irony is the people at the center have
the most fear and the most anger because
in some ways they're the most vested in
that community and they're getting the
most of it
out of it and they have the most fear of
whether they could even survive if that
system didn't exist whereas the people
out in the fringes they're saying oh
people in other systems are surviving
okay and and sometimes they're saying
wow those people seem a little better
off than we do so very often the
greatest tension is not between people
in this system and this system it's
between the people at the center and at
the margins of that system and the
people at the center see the people of
the margins who are asking questions and
looking over the fence so to speak into
another community they see them as
potential betrayers and and so the fear
and the anger is very very
understandable um I I have very little
success and having I can be respectful
and kind and interested in the people at
the center but in terms of changing
their viewpoint I don't think it's going
to change very soon I I spend most of my
time with the people at the margins who
know that something's not working you
have that's
that they're building on sand and that
there's they're living in a glass house
and and that they're and they're
beginning to wonder and and of course
their fear is different their fear is if
I lose this system and if I don't just
join some other system is there any way
for me to find meaning is there any way
for me to find coherence in my life and
and I feel like I've been down that road
I understand that fear and so I try to
in whatever way I can help people it's
it's largely empathy yeah I know what it
feels like I've been there
Gandhi had a saying what was it
first they ignore you then they laugh at
you then they fight you then you win I
would probably say in my experience
there's I'd add one first they ignore
you then they laugh at you then they
fight you then they try to ignore you
some more because what I've experienced
in my writing is that people from my own
religious tradition did ignore and then
mock and then fight but I think what's
been very interesting is it's very hard
when you question the presuppositions
almost the the pre critical assumptions
of a community it's very hard for them
to fight with you because to fight with
you they almost have to acknowledge
these pre critical assumptions so the
fight quickly leads to ignoring and
almost pretending you don't exist which
is one of the reasons excommunications
you know inquisitions leading text
communications are so important because
the person who's questioning the very
foundations the pre critical foundations
of our community you can't fight with
them without the community itself
changing so you just have to exclude
them as quickly as possible that seems
to be what happens but I I think of the
editor of a very popular Christian or
one of the editors of a very popular
Christian magazine who I once met in a

now I don't like you I've read a couple
of your books I completely disagree them
it says but it's strange my sons have
both left Christian faith and if they
ever come to any kind of faith at all
it's probably going to be through your
books some somebody like you he said so
I disagree with you but kind of hope you
succeed and then he walked away
I think we're in a very profound
earthquake and shifting the ground feels
like it's moving out from so many of our
traditional institutions and of course I
come from a Christian background so I
know that best but I've spent a lot of
time with Muslim friends and Jewish
friends and Hindu friends and Buddhist
friends and I what's really remarkable
to me is how this current shift in
consciousness it the combination of
science and philosophy and any number of
other disciplines that are causing us to
question our our previous assumptions
it's affecting every religious community
about every traditional religious
community and it's almost as if there's
a deconstruction and then some people
wonder whether that will just mean the
death of religion but I personally
believe there are great treasures and
our religious traditions to just wipe
them out and throw them away is
incredibly wasteful and I personally
think it leaves vacuums that we are
going to have to fill and so my little
motto is that the antidote to Bad
Religion is usually not no religion but
it's it's good or better religion so I
think what we'll see is a kind of
deconstruction and then this period of
anxiety and difficulty it's almost as if
you're on the trapeze and you've let go
of the old one and you haven't quite
seized that doing yet and that feeling
of weightlessness and it can be both
terrifying and exhilarating it may be
that that's where the word faith
actually takes in some meaning this
sense that I've actually let go of
something which is you know the old word
repentance means rethinking I rethought
something and I had to let it go and but
yet there's a sense of openness open
handedness that there's something new to
be seized
but in that in-between time it's
delicate it's and and I think it caught
calls for a kind of ethical gentleness
with one another
and patience even though it's very
urgent for us to get through this
also just human kindness and
understanding how hard it is I I I
watched this over the last several years
you know the issue of LGBT equality
because one of these boundary breaking
issues for a lot of people and and I had
already gone through my own shift in
this thinking but and after I went
through a shift in my thinking one of my
sons came out and at that moment I felt
myself living between my son's world and
my father's world where this was just
inconceivable and you know because I
love my father and I love my son I could
kind of hold the space for them that was
very hard for my father to make that
reach and I think for my son he just
couldn't understand how my father lived
in a different world but we were able to
love one another in the midst of that
reality I think that's what helps us get
through these times
because I was a Christian pastor for
twenty four years I I think I I know
kind of in my skin and my in my bones
this very difficult balance that
religious leaders have to walk on the
one hand they're supposed to be leading
a community into a genuine encounter
with the divine and at the same time
they have bills to pay and you know
institution to maintain and warring
factions within the community and all
kinds of egos and mistakes and all the
rest in the community that they're
trying to hold together it's not an easy
place to be in and this is one of the
reasons I think that we can that the old
idea of a religious leader simply as
somebody who knows a bunch of religious
lore or religious information and can
operate the the levers of of an
institution it won't help us we actually
need leaders who can embody what is
sometimes called a non-anxious presence
in the middle of the stress to not
separate yourself from the stress to be
in it but to somehow be able to be in it
with charity or affection or or love
toward all the participants even the
ones who are at each other's throats so
to speak and with this sense of
confidence that we're going to get
through this and that there is something

even there I think we have to have some
mercy and compassion for one another you
know a young you know a 28 year old
who's new at this has certain challenges
and certain advantages and a 68 year old
who's been at it a long time has
strengths but also has some weaknesses
so it this to me is a time when we all
have something to offer and we all have
a lot to learn
I see very much this the the the
possibility of something beautiful
emerging from from the the kind of ruins
in some cases of our religious
communities or or the warring factions
I'll just give an example because I grew
up in a very fundamentalist and Bible
obsessed sect I really studied the Bible
unfortunately the way we study the Bible
was to find a way to take every sentence
in every phrase and fit it into a system
of belief but something happens when you
lose confidence in your system of belief
and that starts to crumble around you
and then you go back and look at the
biblical stories and you see oh you know
there is a deeper wisdom there if I let
the stories work one way I try to say it
to people sometimes is that I think in
the ancient world before the science the
scientific worldview and and the methods
of science hypothesis was to tell a
story and just as hypotheses are tested
and either disproved or improved
I think ancient stories would be told
and and then enhanced and developed over
time we we have many examples in
literature where we can see a story that
evolves over time and sometimes though
as soon as the story's written down it
can no longer evolve and then a new
story has to come up that's in tension
with that old story and it's been this
wonderful discovery for me someone who
grew up in such a Bible saturated
environment to kind of rediscover the
Bible as these dueling stories and these
evolving stories and stories that were
in some ways the meaning doesn't come
like the moral of a story but the
meaning comes when you discern a kind of
trajectory and the way these different
stories are told they're leaving things
behind they're embracing new metaphors
and new images in that way you locate
yourself in this long journey of of
searching and truth of holding on to
something gaining something from it but
then seeing I've got to let that go on
except something else that kind of
trapeze and to the next trapeze then you
start to see oh that actually you
actually learn that in this kind of
storyline and unfolding of the biblical
library I think that's really helping
many of us in the Christian faith to
rediscover so many treasures in our own
faith that actually give us the courage
to continue the quest where we are at
this at this point in the journey
well you know a question that I think is
really on the front burner for people in
the Christian tradition is what do we
mean when we say the word God and we in
our tradition we have a whole set of
images and names and that that in some
ways some of them were grabbed and held
for a while and then let go and new ones
emerge others have been remarkably
consistent but here we are in today's
world and knowing what we know and and
knowing something of what we don't know
and experiencing these shifts in
consciousness I think we're at a new
place of needing fresh language for how

maintaining some sense of reverence for

contained in the name but also being

now it's almost as if both of these
